content.title: Jet Lag and Circadian Rhythm Disruption at Conferences
content.summary: Understanding circadian rhythm disruption from travel and evidence-based recovery strategies for conference attendees
key_points: Circadian rhythm is controlled by suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) - the master clock
Recovery rate: ~1 day per time zone crossed (faster westward, slower eastward)
Eastward travel is harder: advancing the clock is more difficult than delaying
Light exposure is the most powerful circadian entrainment tool
Strategic melatonin use (0.5-3mg) can accelerate adaptation
Jet lag impairs memory consolidation, attention, and decision-making
Pre-adaptation (shifting sleep schedule before travel) reduces symptoms

statement.text: Jet lag (circadian dysrhythmia) occurs when rapid travel across time zones desynchronizes the internal circadian clock from the external environment. This misalignment impairs sleep quality, cognitive performance, mood, and physical function - all critical for conference success. Strategic light exposure, sleep timing, and melatonin can accelerate re-entrainment.
statement.formal: Jet Lag Severity ∝ (Time Zones Crossed × Direction Factor); Recovery ≈ 1 day/zone; Eastward > Westward difficulty

explanation.intuition: Your body runs on a 24-hour internal clock synchronized to your home time zone. When you fly across time zones, your internal clock and the external world are out of sync - like having a clock that shows the wrong time. Your body needs time (roughly one day per hour of time difference) to reset.
explanation.key_insight: The direction of travel matters: traveling west 'extends' your day (easier to stay up late), while traveling east 'shortens' it (harder to fall asleep earlier). This is why eastward jet lag typically feels worse and takes longer to resolve.

definitions_glossary.circadian_rhythm: ~24-hour internal biological clock regulating sleep-wake cycles, hormones, and metabolism
definitions_glossary.suprachiasmatic_nucleus: Master circadian pacemaker in hypothalamus; receives light input from retina
definitions_glossary.jet_lag: Temporary sleep disorder from rapid transmeridian travel causing circadian misalignment
definitions_glossary.melatonin: Hormone secreted by pineal gland; signals darkness to circadian system
definitions_glossary.zeitgeber: Environmental cue that entrains circadian rhythm (light is strongest)
definitions_glossary.phase_advance: Shifting circadian rhythm earlier (required for eastward adaptation)
definitions_glossary.phase_delay: Shifting circadian rhythm later (required for westward adaptation)
definitions_glossary.circadian_desynchrony: Internal clock misaligned with external light-dark cycle

pathophysiology.mechanism: Transmeridian travel → Light-dark cycle shift → SCN receives conflicting signals → Peripheral clocks (liver, gut, muscles) lag behind → Multi-system desynchrony → Sleep disruption + Cognitive impairment + GI symptoms + Mood changes

pre_travel.eastward: Shift sleep 30-60min earlier per day for 3 days before departure
pre_travel.westward: Shift sleep 30-60min later per day for 3 days before departure

light_exposure.eastward: Seek bright light in morning; avoid evening light
light_exposure.westward: Seek bright light in evening; avoid early morning light
light_exposure.timing_rule: Avoid light in the 4 hours before your home bedtime

melatonin.timing: Take at destination bedtime, especially for eastward travel

behavioral: Stay awake until local evening (brief naps ≤20min if needed)
Avoid alcohol and caffeine near bedtime

definition.@value: Temporary circadian rhythm disruption from rapid travel across time zones, causing sleep disturbance and impaired daytime function

medicalCode.description: Circadian rhythm sleep disorder, jet lag type

learning_objectives: Understand the biology of circadian rhythm and jet lag
Calculate expected adaptation time for travel
Apply strategic light exposure for faster recovery
Use melatonin appropriately for circadian entrainment
Plan pre-travel adaptation for important conferences
practical_tips: Set watch to destination time upon boarding
If arriving morning, stay awake; if arriving evening, sleep on plane
Use blue light blocking glasses in evening at destination
Get outdoor light exposure during destination morning
Avoid scheduling critical presentations on day 1 after long-haul eastward flights
